title: Set up
text: First, set up the hypothesis test. Since the problem is about a mean, this is a test of a single population mean.
speech: First, set up the hypothesis test. Since the problem is about a mean, this is a test of a single population mean.
pacedSpeech: First, set up the hypothesis test. Since the problem is about a mean, this is a test of a single population mean.

title: Tail
text: Based on the problem, $$H_0$$: $$μ=16.43$$ $$H_a$$: $$μ<16.43$$. The "<" tells you this is left-tailed.
speech: Based on the problem,    h sub 0 :  mu, is equal to 16.43     h sub a :  mu is less than 16.43 . The "<" tells you this is left-tailed.

title: Distribution

title: Find μ
text: We know $$σ=0.8$$ and $$n=15$$. What is μ?

subHints.title: Find μ
subHints.text: What is $$H_0$$? This is the value of μ.

speech: We know  sigma is equal to 0.8  and  n, is equal to 15 . What is μ?

title: P-value
text: Calculate the $$p-value$$ using the normal distribution for a mean. We need to know the sample mean for this.
speech: Calculate the  p minus value  using the normal distribution for a mean. We need to know the sample mean for this.

title: Mean
text: What does the problem say is the sample mean?

title: P-value
text: $$p-value=P\left(x<16\right)=0.0187$$. The $$p-value$$ is the area to the left of the sample mean.

title: Compare

title: Compare
text: Is \alpha less than or greater than the $$p-value$$?
speech: Is \alpha less than or greater than the  p minus value, ?
pacedSpeech: Is \alpha less than or greater than the   p minus value,

title: Interpret
text: Since \alpha>p-value, we would reject $$H_0$$. This means that you reject $$μ=16.43$$. In other words, you do not think Jeffrey swims the 25-yard freestyle in $$16.43$$ seconds but faster with the new goggles. Find the conclusion that matches with this idea.
